discussion.content: Aren't both buildings upgrading to fibre? So why is a media converter needed? You have fibre on both sides then.

comments.content: So basically they rid of the Wireless bridge and they swapped it to Fibre. So yeah at the demarc you`ll be using a media converter before going into the router/firewall.

discussion.content: Honestly I don't understand the question entirely but the question states "at the demarc point" Logically you wouldn't have a router there or something else in the answers, a media converter makes sense. From WiFi - fibre. I didn't even know this was possible.

questions.question_text: Two buildings used to be connected by a wireless bridge, but they are upgrading to fiber. Which of the following new devices would be required at the demarcation points?

discussion.content:
here is what i did
finance 150 IPs I gave 254 IPs /24 btw 172.16.48.1 ~ 172.16.48.254 (.0 network and .255 broadcast)
marketing 78 IPs I gave 126 IPs /25 btw 172.16.49.1 ~ 172.16.49.126 (.0 network and .127 broadcast)
Legal 39 IPs so I gave 62 IPs /26 btw 172.16.49.129 ~ 172.16.49.190 (.128 network and .191 broadcast)
R&D 12 IPs so I gave 14 IPs /28 btw 172.16.49.193 ~ 172.16.49.206 (.192 network and .207 broadcast)
This question seems much more difficult than any other subnetting question I've come across.

comments.content: This is a CCNA level question
Not true. This is cover in CompTIA's Net + objects.
This question is not difficult. It's simply asking for IP address for each department. Look at ostralo's comment.

discussion.content: to figer out the answer u need 10 mnt from the exam time this is to much to work it

How did you go from 172.16.49.0 for finance to 172.16.49.0 network hor marketing?
Please explain.
What is the quickest way to calculate this in the head without writing it down?
I did this and got the correct answer, it took to much time, we do need to know how to do this for N+ but questions like this on the test will take to much time!

This does fall under network+ objectives. However, it is not something that can be solved in 1 minute. As there are a max of 90 questions they say 1 min per question. If anything this has to be a performance based question.
This isn't using VLSM.

comments.content:
The given answer is correct, but the method is wrong. VLSM, u shld start with allocating the largest grp first till the smallest group.

Finance 150 addresses, starting from 172.16.49.38, what is the subnet mask used? If /24, then starting is .49.0 is the NID and 254 addresses, but will overlap the previous allocation. If /25, then only 126 addresses, which falls below the required number.

Ostralo explanation below is correct.

questions.question_text:
A company is expanding and building a new remote branch office. Marketing will need 78 IP addresses, finance will need 150 IP addresses, legal will need 39 IP addresses, and R&D will need 12 IP addresses. The network administrator gives the technician a network of 172.16.48.0/23 and wants the technician to use
VLSM for the design. Which of the following are possible solutions? (Choose three.)

choices.F: The legal department should have a first usable IP address of 172.16.49.190
choices.H: The R&D department should have a last usable IP address of 172.16.49.190.
choices.G: The legal department should have usable IPs ranging from 172.16.49.129 to 172.16.49.190.
choices.B: The R&D department should have 172.16.49.207 as a broadcast address.
choices.C: The R&D department should receive a /27 network.
choices.E: The marketing department should have usable IPs ranging from 172.16.49.129 to 172.16.49.190.
choices.A: The marketing department should receive a /25 network.
choices.D: The finance department should have 172.16.49.127 as a broadcast address.

questions.question_text: After several changes to the network, a technician needs to ensure a client is checking for new hostname and IP pairings. Which of the following commands should the technician use to force new lookups?

discussion.content: ipconfig /flushdns deletes the DNS cahe store on a device. If a website IP address changes the DNS cache will prevent the user from accessing the website. Best thing to do is to empty the cache.
Flushing DNS will clear any IP addresses or other DNS records from your cache
Yeah, that's correct.
Is flushdns right for this?
Spectrum Analyzer - "spectrum" think of WiFi channels.

questions.question_text: A network technician is setting up a WiFi network in a multi-tenant building. When trying to determine the best channel, which of the following is the BEST tool to use?

discussion.content: oh it's my bad C is the best answer
This is the second Faraday question that I am seeing. Is this in the Network+ objectives?

comments.content: it's more in the goals for the security + ......

discussion.content: OK. The answer is C because the question did not mentioned the WIRELESS network types, like an example WIFI , cellular network.

So, the bookstore prohibits customers from accessing the college network. The wording is crap but this distinction makes the Faraday cage the right answer.

Since you are not allowed to access the college network whilst in the bookstore, the Faraday cage would block or redirect the college networks signal thus not allowing anyone in the store to be able to access the network.

I am confused with this one guys...I just do not think the Faraday cage is the best option. I don't know, when you look up Faraday cage, all it talks about how it is good for keeping away EMI ...what does that have to do with this question in particular? 

I can believe that MAC filtering would help with the "BEST method to prevent customers from accessing the wireless network WHILE IN the bookstore"....

Tough one.

comments.content: A sounds like the best answer, yup.

On second thought.... they did say they want people to not be able to access the Wi-Fi from INSIDE the store, so that tells me that the Wi-Fi is coming from OUTSIDE the store, thus it's not THEIR Wi-Fi, but could be the campus' Wi-Fi, thus the cage makes sense...

This question is ridiculously ambiguous. It states that they must prohibit customers from "accessing the wireless network in the building". This can easily be interpreted two ways:

- They don't want anyone accessing ANY wireless network while in the building.
- They don't want anyone accessing the wireless network provided in the building.

Depending on how you interpret their sentence, you can come up with very different answers.

I'm having Clinton trial flashbacks...

discussion.content: MAC address filtering allows you to block traffic coming from certain known machines or devices. The router uses the MAC address of a computer or device on the network to identify it and block or permit the access.
The word 'prohibits' here is very important.

this answer and some comments tell me that some is deliberately is trying to mislead people! a Faraday cage would kill ALL types of signal a wireless signal and cellular for everyone (not just wireless for costumers as the question says). plus it isn't a logical solution anyway! Answer D: a pre shared key makes sense

comments.content: Since they said they don't want anyone to get to the Wi-Fi from inside, that means it's being broadcasted outside.. which means they don't control it.. which means the cage.

discussion.content:
if you implement the faraday cage the whole building not getting any wifi connection due to signal diversion, 
D is the best answer to use preshare key!

questions.question_text:
Due to regulatory requirements, a college bookstore prohibits customers from accessing the wireless network in the building. Which of the following would be the
BEST method to prevent customers from accessing the wireless network while in the bookstore?

choices.B: Require PEAP for authentication to the wireless network.
choices.D: Require a pre-shared key for authentication to the wireless network.
choices.A: Use MAC filtering for authorization to the wireless network.
choices.C: Implement a Faraday cage within the bookstore premises.
